summary: paramyxoviridae is an enveloped virus with a non-segmented negative-sense RNA genome of 15 246 bases. the RNA genome encodes, from the 3′ end, the nucleo- (NP), phospho- (P), V, matrix (M), fusion (F), small hydrophobic (SH), haemagglutinin–neuraminidase (HN) and large (L) proteins. the IFN response is triggered when virus infection results in the generation of molecules, such as dsRNA, that display molecular signatures. the two most important cytoplasmic PRRs for detecting PAMPs produced by RNA viruses are retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) the V protein limits IFN induction by interacting directly with MDA-5. it indirectly inhibits RIG-I by binding to a helicase related to RIG-I. it also blocks IFN signalling by targeting signal transducer and activator of transcription 1 (STAT1) for proteasome-mediated degradation. the ability of PIV5 to circumvent the IFN response is not absolute. plaques of PIV5 are significantly larger on cells that cannot produce and/or respond to IFN compared with IFN-competent cells. however, the virus manages to target STAT1 for proteasome-mediated degradation.
